Cory Doctorow is one of those writers who&rsquo;s able to write so much so quickly, I&rsquo;m left scratching my head.
I&rsquo;ve only read one of his 30 or so fiction and non-fiction books ‚Äî¬†The Lost Cause ‚Äî and while that&rsquo;s already a prolific catalog, the guy also writes not one but two blogs. Pluralistic, his daily link blog, intimidates me: how does this guy have so much to say every day? And how can he balance this with writing books, finding interesting articles on the internet, and maintain a life with chores, eating, and sleeping?
So I did what anybody would do: I read a bunch of essays and interviews with him while watching figure skating on the Olympics.
Like a lot of writers, he has some straightforward advice:
&ldquo;I have a daily writing target. It&rsquo;s been as little as one page/day (250 words) and as much as eight pages/day (2,000 words), and I hit it every single day, no matter where I am. I take off weekends, my birthday, Christmas, and New Year&rsquo;s Day. ‚Ä¶
title: Cory Doctorow's writing routine
